docs.lead_paragraph: Twenty-five years ago this month, Louise Brown became famous just by being born -- the first human conceived outside the body. Doctors removed a single egg from her mother's ovary, combined it with her father's sperm in a laboratory dish and, two and a half days later, placed the resulting eight-cell embryo into her mother's womb. By today's standards, Louise Brown's conception seems rather conventional. Consider, by comparison, Lily and Max Karlin of Florham Park, N.J., who were conceived by in vitro fertilization, or I.V.F., two years ago.

headline.main: After 25 Years, New Ideas in the Prenatal Test Tube

docs.abstract: Article on conceptual revolution started by Louise Brown twenty-five years ago when she became first human conceived outside body in process now known as in vitro fertilization; few would have predicted impact today as one percent of all American babies are born using IVF; new techniques to help parents successfully conceive include in vitro maturation, preimplantation genetic diagnosis and intracytoplasmic sperm injection that specifically addresses male fertility problems; blastocyst transfer, where embryos are matured several days in lab environment before being implanted, was designed in hopes of reducing multiple pregnancies, but appears to increase incidence of twins; nuclear transfer, which is newest possibility for older women to become pregnant, is discussed; procedure is not currently approved for testing and development in US; photo; graph (L)
